subject: Re: [junit] newbie question: how to avoid rerunning fixture code on Â every test
msgSnippet: Point well taken.  However, I should have prefaced that my perspective is that of using one of the TestRunner(s) provided to you as part of the JUnit
messageBody:
Point well taken. However, I should have prefaced that my perspective
is that of using one of the TestRunner(s) provided to you as part of the
JUnit distribution. TestRunner(s) run TestSuites that are built and run
in the fashion I describe regardless if runTest() is overridden in your
child test class. I have run some experiments to show this.

However, if the user overrides runTest(), instantiates their test class,
and calls run() then you are correct.

thanks,
J.P.


junit@egroups.com wrote:
>
> jphedley@... wrote:
> >
> > Err.....  I just spent some time responding to this but my message got
lost
> > since my mail session expired, POS.
> >
> > This is definitely a source of confusion that surprises many; even some
who
> > have worked some time with JUnit.
> >
> > Each test in your suite(e.g., test_underScore1) corresponds to a new
instance
> > of child of TestCase (e.g., SomeNameTest).  Examine how a TestSuite is
> > constructed:
> > 1)statically
> > public static Test suite(){
> >     TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >     suite.addTest(new SomeNameTest("test_underScore1"));
> >     suite.addTest(new SomeNameTest("test_underScore2"));
> >     return suite;
> > }
> > 2)dynamically
> > public static Test suite(){
> >     TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(SomeNameTest.class);
> > }
>
> And what about the case involving "runTest()"?  I haven't done such a
> clear exploratory piece of code, but if you use a runTest method, each
> TestCase class appears to be treated as a single test when doing dynamic
> suites.
>
> --
> David Corbin
